thread.title: Justin Bieber can't eat lunch without being mobbed by fans and it's sad
thread.title_full: Justin Bieber can't eat lunch without being mobbed by fans and it's sad

author: Johnny Lieu
title: Justin Bieber can't eat lunch without being mobbed by fans and it's sad
text:
The price of fame, hey.
Justin Bieber couldn't get away from the hordes of smartphone-armed fans while recently on tour in Australia. Not even on a secret island in Queensland .
But when the popstar tried to sit down for lunch at Sydney chicken joint, Chargrill Charlie's on Friday afternoon (you know, as normal people do) but became obvious just how much it would suck to be him.
SEE ALSO: Justin Bieber is sick of overeager fans, and he ain't afraid to say so
He was met by a large gang of fans, who police kept at bay while he ate. Undeterred, they just stood there — staring at him while he ate his chicken and greens. It looks like the saddest lunch ever.
Probably the first time I've felt sorry for Justin Bieber. The poor guy can't even go for chicken without a mob of baying fans tailing him. pic.twitter.com/yzgLYr24y2
— Joe Ellison (@Chevychased) March 17, 2017
Saw Justin Bieber eating lunch. First time I've felt bad for the guy. How hard it must be to be smothered where ever you go
— pixelhazard (@pixelhazard) March 17, 2017
Finishing his lunch, the mayhem didn't end as he tried to run away from the growing number of teenage fans and paparazzi.
(10) Another video of Justin Bieber spotted out in Sydney, Australia today. (March 17) pic.twitter.com/wGelKVVaHS
— JustinBieberCrew.com (@JBCGiveaway) March 17, 2017
Bieber had some choice words in his encounters with fans, saying: "The more you guys scream and act like animals, the less we can have a conversation."
Say it louder for the people in the back biebo pic.twitter.com/lZkVe1fvsi
— j (@godstanbieber) March 17, 2017
Or: "Who touched my face, don't touch my face." Sigh.
"Who touched my face? Don't touch my face" pic.twitter.com/gKoqG76wHK
— j (@godstanbieber) March 17, 2017
It's no wonder Bieber thanked a police officer called "Dennis" who helped him get around the fan-clogged streets of Sydney suburb, Mosman.
Yes there's the fame, and the money. But who'd actually want to be a celebrity?
Miss you Dennis
A post shared by Justin Bieber (@justinbieber) on Mar 17, 2017 at 2:59am PDT
Not us, mate.
